ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course is outside my field, and I feel like I came out with a new set of knowledge about Europe and Portugal.
I learned about the Portuguese empire, its inner workings, its administrations, culture, and formation. It gave me a greater understanding of the formation of colonial Brazil and the slave trade.
Far greater knowledge of Portugal and its history of contact with the wider world

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength was that seminar discussions were very insightful. Weakness: too much focus on small facts in the readings.
The readings were superb and very engaging. They were well-chosen and informative. I wish other people in the course engaged with the material as deeply so as to stimulate the discussion further.

In general I found the course very well structured, what I would suggest would be a greater emphasis on establishing chronology week to week, as it sometimes became unclear when the events we were discussing was taking place

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I recommend this course to any student who is interested in world history, colonial Latin America, early modern Europe, imperial history, world trade, and the formation of nation-states.
Yes, the course provides important insight into an under-explored subject in the development of Europe and European contact with the wider world
